benchmark_details.name: MulCogBench (Multi-modal Cognitive Benchmark Dataset)
benchmark_details.overview: MulCogBench is a multi-modal cognitive benchmark dataset collected from native Chinese and English participants, which encompasses a variety of cognitive data including subjective semantic ratings, eye-tracking, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), and magnetoencephalography (MEG). The dataset is used to evaluate the relationship between computational language models and cognitive data.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a dataset for evaluating the cognitive processing capabilities of computational language models in relation to human cognitive data.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Cognitive data contains noise and may represent multiple cognitive functions, making direct correlation difficult.

data.source: Collected from native Chinese and English participants across various experiments.
data.size: 170,331 eye-tracking samples, 672 words in word semantic ratings for Chinese and 535 for English.
data.annotation: Manual annotation by experts and collected via experiments with human participants.

methodology.calculation: Computed similarity between cognitive data and embeddings of computational language models.
methodology.interpretation: Higher Pearson correlation indicates better encoding of linguistic information by the computational model.
methodology.baseline_results: Results show significant correlations between language models and human cognitive data.
methodology.validation: Validation through various cognitive modalities and linguistic units.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Analysis across languages includes both Chinese and English participants.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All cognitive data collected under the approval of the Institutional Review Board.
